entry.title: Managing Test Anxiety
entry.content:
Feeling somewhat anxious or stressed before an exam is quite normal for most students. At times the tension helps you to rise to the challenge. Do you feel some or all of the following prior to writing a test?

  • Nervousness/Nausea
  • Difficulty sleeping the night before
  • Butterflies in your stomach
  • Blanking or not being able to remember anything

These are common symptoms associated with test-writing anxiety that you can learn to manage effectively. Try some of the following strategies to calm yourself and help you to focus during exam time.

Before the Exam:

  • Accept that feeling anxious prior to a test is a normal feeling.
  • Associate with positive, focused classmates.
  • Take some time to relax before you go to bed the night before your test.
  • Arrive slightly before the exam prepared with the necessary pens, pencils, calculators or reference materials (if they are allowed).
  • Visualize your successful completion of the test.
  • Use positive self-talk such as I can do this.

During the Exam

  • Write anything you know or want to remember on the back of your exam such as formulas, steps in a process, or dates in a timeline. It serves as a reminder that you do know something.
  • Begin with a question to which you know the answer to build your self-confidence.
  • Tense and relax muscles where you feel tension. For example, raise/lower/ roll your shoulders, roll your head from side to side, or flex your fingers.
  • Concentrate on an object or spot in the room for a short period of time.
  • Focus on your breathing, slowly inhaling through your nose and exhaling through your mouth.
  • Use positive self-talk such as I am doing a good job; When I work/read carefully I can figure this out, etc.

Writing an exam is a stressful situation. There is no substitution for knowing your course material but you can do your best to remain calm, positive, and focused. When you feel in control, you will do a better job of demonstrating your understanding of the course content.

If you are serious about your success on the diploma exams – DIPLOMAX is here to help you succeed!

entry.title: Test Response Strategies
entry.content:
There are many strategies to help you maximize your performance on quizzes, unit tests, and final exams. The following provides information on three common strategies that you may find useful.

Five-Pass Strategy

This strategy has five steps or ‘passes’ for answering exam questions:

  1. Browsing Pass – scan the entire exam; note question formats, marks for each section, instructions
  2. First Answering Pass – answer questions you know the answer to and can complete quickly; maintain a brisk pace
  3. Second Answering Pass – answer questions left during the first pass that require more effort per mark; work the questions through until you experience an impasse or it is taking too long; maintain a steady pace
  4. Third Answering Pass – complete all partial answers; guess at any true/false and multiple choice questions you have left and attempt any questions still unanswered; all questions should now have full or partial answers
  5. Review Pass – check all answers and calculations as time permits

Three-Pass Strategy

This strategy has three steps or ‘passes’ for answering exam questions; is an abbreviated version of the five pass method:

  1. Overview – scan the entire exam; note question formats, marks for each section, instructions, and questions you can complete easily and quickly
  2. Second Pass – answer all questions you can complete without too much difficulty stopping when the question becomes too challenging or is taking too much time
  3. Last Pass – answer any questions that are left; guess and provide partial answers if necessary

Problem-Solving Strategy

This strategy has four steps to work through in answering a problem; the problem can be a word problem or a calculation problem:

  1. Understand the problem – What is the question? Do I have the information I need?
  2. Develop a Plan – Have I done something similar before? Can I break the question down into smaller parts?
  3. Carry out the Plan – Is my process logical? Have I shown all of the steps in the process? Have I included the correct units of measurement?
  4. Look Back – Have I answered the question? Does my answer make sense?

When writing an exam it is important that you use strategies that work for you – strategies that you understand and can use confidently. An exam is not the time to “try something new”.

If you are serious about your success on the diploma exams – DIPLOMAX is here to help you succeed!

entry.title: Test Writing Tips: Part 2
entry.content:
Here are the “Last Five” of the Top Ten Test Writing Tips that may help you to write a stronger exam!

  • Start with a question for which you know the answer. You do not have to start at the beginning of the test. Knowing the answer to the first question you try builds your confidence and sets a positive tone for the rest of the exam.
  • Look for clues and information in one part of the test that helps you to answer questions in another part. Useful information is often included in diagrams, charts, graphs, photos, and source information such as the year a photo was taken or where the author lived. Pictures, charts, graphs, and diagrams may provide a context for the question you are expected to answer.
  • Answer every question even if you have to guess. Leaving a question blank is guaranteed to earn you zero marks. An educated guess in a multiple choice question gives you an opportunity to ‘luck out’.
  • Read over all of your answers before you hand in your test. You want to be sure you’ve answered all the questions, that your response satisfies what was asked, and that your calculations are accurate. Where necessary include the units of measurement.
  • Finish your answers to written response or essay questions in point form if you are running out of time. This shows the marker that you have understood the question and have an organized and thoughtful response – just not enough time for complete sentences.

When writing an exam, there is no substitute for knowing your course material really well but you can bolster your performance by staying in the exam room for the entire amount of time and reviewing your answers. Take a short ‘mental break’ by rolling your head from side to side and/or shrugging your shoulders. In thinking about the overall test or reviewing specific questions, you may remember additional information to add to some of your written responses or help you with the multiple choice questions.

If you are serious about your success on the diploma exams – DIPLOMAX is here to help you succeed!

entry.title: Test Writing Tips: Part 1
entry.content:
There are two components to doing well on an exam.
One – you need to know your material.
Two – you need to know how to write the test. Knowing how to write the test gives you the best opportunity to demonstrate your knowledge and understanding of the course content.

Here are tips that may help you write a better exam.

  • Start your exam by taking a few deep breaths to calm yourself. If you are feeling anxious, use positive self-talk such as, ‘I can do this’, ‘I’m ready for this’, or ‘This is going to be my best test result’.
  • Immediately write down any information that you do not want to forget. For example, on a math exam, write down the formulas you may need to know and use for the exam before you begin to look at the exam instructions and questions.
  • Look over the entire test paper or booklet to see what type(s) of and how many questions there are in total. This gives you an overview of the specific content and concepts that are being assessed, the value or number of marks for each question, and the question format(s) to which you need to respond.
  • Budget your time for each section of the exam before you begin answering any part of the test. You do not want to spend a lot of time on a portion of the exam that is worth only a small percentage of the total number of marks.
  • Read all of the instructions carefully before you begin answering any questions. It is important that you know what you are expected to do and what specifically is required in your response.

Check out the blog next week for second part of this series!

If you are serious about your success on the diploma exams – DIPLOMAX is here to help you succeed!

entry.title: Study Schedules – Long-term, Short-term, and PANIC!
entry.content:
Have you ever read the story of The Hare and the Tortoise? It is a delightful children’s story of a race between two animal friends who each are confident of their ability to win a race. The Hare sets off to a speedy start and covers a significant amount of territory before deciding he has enough of a head start on the Tortoise that he can stop for a rest. He settles under a shady tree and enjoys a nap, confident that he can sprint to the finish line well before the Tortoise can catch up to him.

The Tortoise leaves the start line slowly plodding along the race path. Though not a flashy racer, he keeps a steady pace and remains focused on getting to the finish line. He passes the sleeping Hare and soon sees the finish line looming in the distance. As the Tortoise is within steps of crossing the finish line and winning the race, the Hare wakes up. He realizes he needs to make a spirited sprint to overtake the Tortoise. Unfortunately, the Hare’s panicked dash for the finish line is “too little too late”. The Tortoise, although a long shot, wins the race and the brazen, confident Hare is left humiliated and searching for an explanation for his loss.

There are many analogies that can be drawn between the race strategies of the story characters and long-term, short-term, and panic study schedules.

Long-term Study Schedules generally are implemented well in advance of exam time and require you to set aside regular study time on an on-going basis. Like the Tortoise a slow and steady approach helps to win the race. The advantage of a long-term study schedule is that once you establish your study routine, it is quite easy to maintain – and shorter, regular periods of study give you the most benefit!

Short-term Study Schedules are often implemented several days or weeks before an exam and require you to prioritize the time you spend on each topic or concept. It may be difficult to find a “starting point”. Do you focus on the things that are most important in the subject or on the concepts that are most challenging to you? Like the Hare, your focus may change before the end of the race. You may skim over content that you feel you have a firm understanding of in favor of focusing on topics that feel less confident about. Your focus may not be as consistent or as strong as it needs to be for the duration of your study or exam preparation time. The advantage of a short-term study schedule is that you gain a sense of confidence as you “check off” the topics and concepts you feel confident about.

Panic Study Schedules usually happen “the night before” the exam – when you realize that you do not have enough time to adequately prepare for your exam. Although this study schedule requires the least amount of time commitment, it rarely allows you to achieve your potential. Like the Hare, leaving too much to the end makes it impossible to finish what needs to be done. However, any effort is better than doing nothing.

To achieve the grades you want requires effort on your part. A long-term study schedule gives you the best chance for success. A short-term study schedule may work well in a course where you have a strong understanding of the concepts. A Panic Study Schedule is better than not studying at all but may not help you to achieve your course goals over the semester or school year.

Does your study strategy resemble the race strategy of the Hare or the Tortoise?

If you are serious about your success on the diploma exams – DIPLOMAX is here to help you succeed!

entry.title: DIPLOMAX Prep Gives Students Leg Up for Alberta Diploma Exams
entry.content:
High-stakes diploma exams in January and June are always a challenge for grade 12 students. These provincial exams count for 50% of a student’s final grade with the other 50% coming from school-based assessments.

For a variety of reasons, it is becoming more and more common for students to seek assistance beyond the classroom in preparing for the diploma exams. Entrance requirements for many post-secondary institutions have increased over the years so students need better grades to gain admittance. The competition is extremely keen for faculties that have quotas and only take the top echelon of applicants. Then there are the numerous scholarships available for the students who have the top grades!

Teachers work very diligently to get through the extensive, mandated curriculum but often find little time left in the semester for completing a review of the course content. Students are now looking to external sources for the comprehensive review that will give them the “edge” they need to boost their diploma mark – and open the doors to the future they are seeking.

DIPLOMAX exam prep classes provide students with what they are looking for in preparing for the high-stake, provincial diploma exams. The focused 16-hour review classes in English 30-1, Social Studies 30-1, Biology 30, Chemistry 30, Math 30-1, Math 30-2, Physics 30 and Science 30 are offered on Friday, Saturday, and Sunday over several weekends in January and June at the University of Alberta campus in Edmonton.

As soon as students complete their DIPLOMAX registration they have immediate access to a comprehensive Study Notes package which they use to support their home study program. In addition to the Study Notes package, students are provided with tips and strategies for writing exams, suggestions for handling exam anxiety, calculator tricks, and effective study hints.

More detailed information about DIPLOMAX exam prep classes and the course schedule are available on the web site www.primetimelearning.ca If you are still uncertain about what DIPLOMAX can do to help you, read the student evaluation comments! Every student completes an evaluation at the end of each DIPLOMAX class. Currently the satisfaction rate is 94%.

If you are serious about your success on the diploma exams – DIPLOMAX is here to help you succeed!

entry.title: DIPLOMAX’S ELECTRONIC STUDY NOTES – PROVIDES SEMESTER SUPPORT
entry.content:
Complete your on-line DIPLOMAX registration for the January classes at www.primetimeleaning.ca and get your electronic Study Notes package IMMEDIATELY!!

Each student registered in a DIPLOMAX review class receives a complimentary copy of the Study Notes package for that course. Once you complete your registration, you can download the Study Notes package to your personal device or print your own copy. The Study Notes package is approximately 150 pages of notes, tips, practice questions, reminders, etc. You can use the Study Notes package to support your independent studying at home, to prepare for class quizzes, unit tests, homework assignments, and written assignments.

Sample questions, with step-by-step instructions for solving subject-specific problems are part of the electronic Study Notes package. Download or print a single copy of the Study Notes for your personal use at home. The earlier you register online – the longer you will have access to the Study Notes to assist you in your home study!

The website www.primetimelearning.ca is active and accepting registrations for all subjects. Space is limited – guarantee yourself a spot by registering NOW!

If you are serious about your success on the diploma exams – DIPLOMAX is here to help you succeed!

entry.title: DIPLOMAX ADVANTAGE — the PrimeTime Learning GUARANTEE
entry.content:
PrimeTime Learning has offered over 36,000 DIPLOMAX review classes since 1995 in English 30, Math 30-1 and Math 30-2, Biology 30, Chemistry 30, Physics 30, Science 30, and Social Studies 30-1. Highly qualified instructors have helped students who have taken DIPLOMAX review classes raise their diploma mark anywhere from 5-20% over their term mark! Not only is the student satisfaction rate at 94%, but DIPLOMAX offers you the Prime Time Leaning Guarantee.

The PrimeTime Learning Guarantee assures you of the following.

  • Value – When you enroll in DIPLOMAX you receive a fully targeted review, practical test writing strategies, and a comprehensive Study Notes package for that subject.
  • Flexibility – When you enroll in DIPLOMAX and cannot attend all scheduled classes, or if you find you need more help in the same course, you can access subsequent session classes in the same course at no additional cost.
  • Satisfaction – If you have previously taken DIPLOMAX and decide to rewrite that diploma exam, you can take the same course again for free.

Check out the DIPLOMAX January schedule on the web site www.primetimelearning.ca and get immediate access to your complimentary Study Notes package when you complete your registration.

If you are serious about your success on the diploma exams – DIPLOMAX is here to help you succeed!

entry.title: Diplomax Is Going Social
entry.content:

If you are serious about your success on the diploma exams – DIPLOMAX is here to help you succeed!
